issue.title: problem with z.nativeEnum with optional()

repository.name: zod
repository.description: TypeScript-first schema validation with static type inference

issue.body:
Hi, pls help me with validation of optional field of nativeEnum

https://codesandbox.io/s/react-hook-form-nestedvalue-forked-6gh4n?file=/src/App.tsx

related issue https://github.com/react-hook-form/react-hook-form/issues/3985

body:
Hi @kerosan 
Thanks for reporting, it seems the value is an empty string that's why you get this error. 
`select: undefined` is transformed to `select: ""`.

@bluebill1049 I'm not sure to have time to find a fix
maybe worth sending a question at Zod. hook form only throw the data at the `schema.safeParse` `schema.safeParse(values, options);` and this is the `values` `{name: "Name", select: ""}`
But form is invalid and submit don't work ðŸ˜¥

Thanks @jorisre makes sense, we return an empty string for all native input, for example, `select` and `input`, undefined is not applicable for native input. for radio input, we are returning its selected `value`, if nothing selected, we return '' as well.
Good to know ! thanks, where can I find this information is the documentation ?
@bluebill1049 it's not only about radio buttons, in my project I use nativeEnum for drop down component and method .optional() works same

@jorisre I don't think this is documented... which is my bad.

@kerosan that's the thing for native form behavior that input select will be removed from the submission:

Not: 
`select: ''`or `select: undefined`

Result: 
` `

For the sake of consistency for all native form behavior, I made a decision to make them all return an empty string when nothing is selected, checked, or inputted. It's by design and could be a bad design for example at the current example, but in order to change such behavior, it will lead to a breaking change for all existing applications. I am happy to discuss the idealy return result for none checked radio button and check box (single and multiple) as well.

For now I have no any idea which could be better than workaround ðŸ˜‘
Thx for your time ðŸ™ƒ

Thanks for understanding @kerosan, let's leave this issue open and have some good discussion. perhaps we can resolve this issue in the next breaking change. it's a tricky one, you want to keep it simple at the time, not with a surprise like above. we just need to find a good balance.

options are:

1. none-selected or checked: '' **(CURRENT)**
easiest (easy to document too), less logic, remember once apply everywhere.

2. none-selected or checked: `undefined` | `null`
require good documentation for different behavior.

3. none-selected or checked: remove from the submission (same as disabled)
follow the HTML standard, more logic, and some surprise when an input has been registered.

let me know your thought @jorisre.
